title: Can ChatGPT help me open the correct PDF?
text:
Hi everyone,
Welcome to my first post! Today, I‚Äôm looking at ChatGPT‚Äôs ability to do understand the structure of Census data. The data are organized into different PDFs as follows.

Part 1: United States and Geographic Divisions
Part 2: Akron, OH ‚Äì Des Moines, IA
Part 3: Detroit, MI ‚Äì Memphis, TN
Part 4: Miami, FL ‚Äì Salt Lake City, UT
Part 5: San Antonio, TX ‚Äì Youngstown, OH


The task
I was curious if ChatGPT would be able to tell me which section would contain data for Philadelphia.



Not a great start


Inspired by the concept of prewarming or internal retrieval described in Prompt Engineering for Generative AI (Phoenix and Taylor 2024), I decided to ask ChatGPT if it could find a pattern in the file structures. Then, referencing our previous exchange where it discovered the pattern, I would ask it to try the task again.



Better!


Ok, time for the internal retrieval to shine.



Almost there‚Ä¶



Pros: ChatGPT was able to remember that it had previously found that the files were ordered alphabetically when I started the next prompt with ‚ÄúWith that in mind‚Äù.


Cons:  ChatGPT is not correctly retrieving the order of the alphabet.

After expressing some doubt in the alphabetization, ChatGPT was able to provide me with the correct answer.

And just to be sure, I asked it about a different US city, and it was able to complete the task.



So, could this have been done all in one prompt?
I closed out my current session of ChatGPT and tried to create one prompt that would make ChatGPT do some sort of internal retrieval.
I ended up trying this:

Hi! I have a two part question. These are pdf names that have housing data for various US cities in 1950‚Ä¶.


Question 1: Why do you think Akron, OH comes before Des Moines, IA, and Des Moines, IA comes before Detroit, MI? Explain your reasoning. Question 2: Which pdf do you think Philadelphia, PA would be in? Explain your reasoning.

ChatGPT was able to correctly answer Question 1: saying ‚ÄúThe cities are likely listed in alphabetical order (from A to Z), which is why Akron, OH appears before Des Moines, IA, and Des Moines, IA comes before Detroit, MI‚Äù.
But when it came to Question 2, there was more work still to be done.

Then I thought maybe a three part question would help:

Question 1: Why do you think Akron, OH comes before Des Moines, IA, and Des Moines, IA comes before Detroit, MI? Explain your reasoning. Question 2: Can you please print out the order of the alphabet? Question 3: Which pdf do you think Philadelphia, PA would be in? Explain your reasoning.


Sigh! I will have to try this again some other time once I‚Äôve learned more about prompting strategies.

title: Table transcription test
text:
Introduction
Using historical data is pretty fun, but it often involves some grunt work. Sometimes data isn‚Äôt available in a tabular format and needs to be manually transcribed so that it is ready for analysis. Today, I‚Äôm going to build off my first blog post and see if LLMs are able to transcribe values of a table for me.
I‚Äôm going to continue working with the 1950 Census of Housing, linked here. Some of the scans are very easy for me to read, and others are fuzzier. Let‚Äôs see if GPT-4o is up for the test!

Warm-up exercise: an easy example
Let‚Äôs see if ChatGPT can read this clear scan. 

from openai import OpenAI
import os
import base64
import requests

from dotenv import load_dotenv
# Load API key
_ = load_dotenv()

def encode_image(image_path):
  with open(image_path, "rb") as image_file:
    return base64.b64encode(image_file.read()).decode('utf-8')

client = OpenAI()



prompt = 'Describe this image of a table. Suppose you needed to transcribe the data into a .csv file. How many columns would the .csv file have, and what would their names be? How many rows would there be? Think it though. Then, transcribe the data into a semicolon delimited file' 

base64_image = encode_image('img/img1.png')

response = client.chat.completions.create(
    model="gpt-4o",
    messages=[
        {
          "role": "user",
          "content": [
            {"type": "text", "text": prompt},
            {
              "type": "image_url",
              "image_url": {
                "url": f"data:image/jpeg;base64,{base64_image}"
              },
            },
          ],
        }
      ],
)


print(response.choices[0].message.content)

To transcribe the data into a .csv file, you first need to understand the structure of the table. Here's the breakdown:

### Columns
There are 13 columns in the table with the following headers:

1. Subject
2. Total occupied: Total
3. Total occupied: 1 dwelling unit, detached
4. Total occupied: Other 1, and 2 dwelling unit
5. Total occupied: 3 and 4 dwelling unit
6. Total occupied: 5 to 9 dwelling unit
7. Total occupied: 10 dwelling unit or more
8. Owner occupied: Total
9. Owner occupied: 1 dwelling unit, detached
10. Owner occupied: All other dwelling units
11. Renter occupied: Total
12. Renter occupied: 1 dwelling unit, detached
13. Renter occupied: Other 1, and 2 dwelling unit
14. Renter occupied: 3 and 4 dwelling unit
15. Renter occupied: 5 to 9 dwelling unit
16. Renter occupied: 10 dwelling unit or more

### Rows
There are six rows in total:

1. Header row
2. All occupied units
3. 1945 or later
4. 1940 to 1944
5. 1939 or earlier
6. Not reported

Now, let's transcribe the data into a semicolon-delimited format:

```plaintext
Subject;Total occupied: Total;Total occupied: 1 dwelling unit, detached;Total occupied: Other 1, and 2 dwelling unit;Total occupied: 3 and 4 dwelling unit;Total occupied: 5 to 9 dwelling unit;Total occupied: 10 dwelling unit or more;Owner occupied: Total;Owner occupied: 1 dwelling unit, detached;Owner occupied: All other dwelling units;Renter occupied: Total;Renter occupied: 1 dwelling unit, detached;Renter occupied: Other 1, and 2 dwelling unit;Renter occupied: 3 and 4 dwelling unit;Renter occupied: 5 to 9 dwelling unit;Renter occupied: 10 dwelling unit or more
All occupied units;232,265;167,920;31,160;16,225;11,055;5,905;128,110;117,365;10,745;104,155;50,555;24,225;14,940;8,680;5,755
1945 or later;62,332;49,792;5,257;3,300;2,277;1,706;42,380;40,520;1,860;19,952;9,272;4,040;3,131;1,802;1,706
1940 to 1944;30,974;25,940;1,902;357;1,580;1,195;22,292;21,252;1,040;8,682;4,688;1,464;357;1,053;1,120
1939 or earlier;129,422;86,542;22,032;11,457;6,672;2,719;60,170;53,814;7,356;69,252;32,728;17,084;10,409;5,379;3,682
Not reported;9,529;5,649;1,967;1,111;522;280;3,270;2,784;486;6,259;2,865;1,627;1,044;443;280
```

Ensure each value is separated by a semicolon, and commas within numbers are preserved as shown.


I‚Äôm pretty impressed with the output, but it‚Äôs not quite good enough to be able to trust 100% without double checking the numbers. I stared at the output for a little bit before realizing that one of the values in the bottom right of the pdf, 2,648, was transcribed as 3,682.



ChatGPT‚Äôs output





The ‚Äú3,682‚Äù in question


This is a little disheartening! Just to be sure, I‚Äôm going to ask ChatGPT to read only this one number specifically to see if the results improve. Maybe the size of the table it needed to transcribe seemed overwhelming, or the prompt I gave it was too long.

prompt = 'What number is this?' 

base64_image = encode_image('img/img3.png')

completion = client.chat.completions.create(
    model="gpt-4o",
    n=3,
    messages=[
        {
          "role": "user",
          "content": [
            {"type": "text", "text": prompt},
            {
              "type": "image_url",
              "image_url": {
                "url": f"data:image/jpeg;base64,{base64_image}"
              },
            },
          ],
        }
      ],
)

response = completion.choices[0].message.content


for rnum, resp in enumerate(completion.choices,1): 
    display((f'Response {rnum}: {resp.message.content}'))

'Response 1: The number is 2,648.'


'Response 2: The number is 2,648.'


'Response 3: The number is 2,648.'


Yes, ChatGPT, that‚Äôs correct! So maybe the issue was that I assigned too big of a task, making ChatGPT get ‚Äútired‚Äù.


The test
Given that my intended warm-up round was not exactly a walk in the park, I‚Äôm going to make sure to not give ChatGPT too many numbers to transcribe in one prompt. However, I do want to see how it handles fuzzy text. Let‚Äôs try with this image now.

The row names are pretty fuzzy, so I‚Äôm excited to see what the LLM is able to make out.

prompt = 'Describe this image of a table. Suppose you needed to transcribe the data into a .csv file. How many columns would the .csv file have, and what would their names be? How many rows would there be? Think it though. Then, transcribe the data into a semicolon delimited file' 

base64_image = encode_image('img/img4.png')

response = client.chat.completions.create(
    model="gpt-4o",
    messages=[
        {
          "role": "user",
          "content": [
            {"type": "text", "text": prompt},
            {
              "type": "image_url",
              "image_url": {
                "url": f"data:image/jpeg;base64,{base64_image}"
              },
            },
          ],
        }
      ],
)


print(response.choices[0].message.content)

To transcribe the table into a .csv file, we first identify the columns and rows.

### Columns

There are 7 columns in the table:
1. Subject
2. Total
3. 1 dwelling unit, detached
4. Other 1, and 2 dwelling unit
5. 3 and 4 dwelling unit
6. 5 to 9 dwelling unit
7. 10 dwelling unit or more

### Rows

There are 5 rows including the header row:
1. Header
2. All occupied units
3. Year built: 1940 or earlier
4. Year built: 1940 to 1949
5. Year built: 1950 or later
6. Year built: Not reported

### Transcription to a Semicolon Delimited File

Here's how the data would look in a semicolon-delimited format:

```
Subject;Total;1 dwelling unit, detached;Other 1, and 2 dwelling unit;3 and 4 dwelling unit;5 to 9 dwelling unit;10 dwelling unit or more
All occupied units;35,460;23,210;5,320;2,375;1,685;450
1940 or earlier;13,426;11,063;1,196;473;593;101
1940 to 1949;4,737;4,351;251;73;29;27
1950 or later;15,230;12,212;3,678;1,744;1,004;242
Not reported;1,599;1,185;195;79;59;81
```

This setup ensures the data is organized and easy to import into a program that can process .csv files.





Not quite


The screenshot I provided was admittedly hard to read, but I thought ChatGPT would be able to make out the difference between the blurry ‚Äúearlier‚Äù and the blurry ‚Äúlater‚Äù. Let‚Äôs see what happens if I focus its attention on these words.


prompt = 'There are 4 lines of text under the header "YEAR BUILT" in this image. What do they say? Reply only with your transcriptions of the text below the header "YEAR BUILT". Separate each of the 4 lines with quotations' 

base64_image = encode_image('img/img6.png')

completion = client.chat.completions.create(
    model="gpt-4o",
    n=3,
    messages=[
        {
          "role": "user",
          "content": [
            {"type": "text", "text": prompt},
            {
              "type": "image_url",
              "image_url": {
                "url": f"data:image/jpeg;base64,{base64_image}"
              },
            },
          ],
        }
      ],
)

response = completion.choices[0].message.content


for rnum, resp in enumerate(completion.choices,1): 
    display((f'Response {rnum}: {resp.message.content}'))

'Response 1: "1949 or later" "1939 to 1948" "1938 or earlier" "Not reported"'


'Response 2: "1980 or later" "1940 to 1979" "1939 or earlier" "Not reported"'


'Response 3: "1949 or later"  \n"1940 to 1949"  \n"1939 or earlier"  \n"Not reported"'


This seems to just be a lot harder than I thought it would be. At least with its attention focused, it can consistently identify the word ‚Äúlater‚Äù vs the word ‚Äúearlier‚Äù, which it was not able to do before. It‚Äôs impressive that the categories make sense looking at one response at a time, at least for the first 2 responses- there is no overlap between the year ranges, and all years are covered. This indicates some level of logical reasoning. The third response would be double counting 1949 data in two of its categories.
Finally, I‚Äôm curious to see if o1 will be any better than GPT-4o at this.

prompt = 'There are 4 lines of text under the header "YEAR BUILT" in this image. What do they say? Reply only with your transcriptions of the text below the header "YEAR BUILT". Separate each of the 4 lines with quotations' 

base64_image = encode_image('img/img6.png')

completion = client.chat.completions.create(
    model="o1",
    n=3,
    messages=[
        {
          "role": "user",
          "content": [
            {"type": "text", "text": prompt},
            {
              "type": "image_url",
              "image_url": {
                "url": f"data:image/jpeg;base64,{base64_image}"
              },
            },
          ],
        }
      ],
)

response = completion.choices[0].message.content


for rnum, resp in enumerate(completion.choices,1): 
    display((f'Response {rnum}: {resp.message.content}'))

'Response 1: "1961 or later"  \n"1939 to 1941"  \n"1939 or earlier"  \n"Not reported"'


'Response 2: "1949 or later"  \n"1939 to 1944"  \n"1939 or earlier"  \n"Not reported"  '


'Response 3: "1939 or later"  \n"1939 to 1941"  \n"1939 or earlier"  \n"Not reported"  '


I wish I had timed it, but o1 took MUCH longer to run than GPT-4o. Response 2 here is the closest we have gotten so far, but the first line should say 1945. It‚Äôs crazy that all 3 responses got the third line correctly. Well, looks like humans are going to be transcribing historical data for at least a little while longer.

title: Comparing Image Generation Models
text:
Introduction
OpenAI came out with their new 4o Image Generation this week, and I‚Äôm curious how its output compares to image results from DALL¬∑E 3 and Gemini 2.0 Flash.
I‚Äôm going to test this out today using a prompt that asks for a picture of someone standing in Washington Square West, a neighborhood in Philadelphia.


OpenAI‚Äôs 4o Image Generation
Inspired by the image generation example in the product release, I‚Äôm going to create a prompt that is:

Very detailed
Shows a person
Shows text

Here‚Äôs my prompt:

A wide image taken with a phone of a woman wearing a T-Shirt that has a large La Colombe logo on it. She is standing at 9th and Pine in Philadelphia, PA, in the Washington Square West neighborhood. There are cherry blossoms blooming nearby. She holds a sign. It says, in the style of an ‚ÄúI heart New York‚Äù sign:
(Top) I love Washington Square West
(Bottom) Best neighborhood in Philadelphia!
In the background, a SEPTA bus is whizzing by. The overall schene is beautiful and is meant to inspire people to move to the Washington Square West neighborhood.

Here‚Äôs the initial output: 
Quite impressive. I ran up against some rate limits, so I‚Äôm not going to be able to regenerate this today.


Gemini Flash 2.0 Experimental
I gave Gemini the same prompt as I gave OpenAI. It produced an image much more quickly, and the result was not nearly as good! 
Here are a few re-generations:  
There‚Äôs lots of variation across generations. The woman changes, as does the branding of the SEPTA bus! (These SEPTA logos must be from before I moved to Philadelphia‚Äì I can‚Äôt say I‚Äôve ever seen them before).
Let‚Äôs see to what extent I can edit the image. I‚Äôm going to ask for the sign to now appear handwritten.  Pretty good!


DALL¬∑E 3
Let‚Äôs see what DALL¬∑E 3 is able to do when given the same prompt.


Show the code
from openai import OpenAI
import os
import base64
import requests

from dotenv import load_dotenv
# Load API key
_ = load_dotenv()

def encode_image(image_path):
  with open(image_path, "rb") as image_file:
    return base64.b64encode(image_file.read()).decode('utf-8')

client = OpenAI()




Show the code
image_prompt = '''
A wide image taken with a phone of a woman wearing a T-Shirt that has a large La Colombe logo on it. She is standing at 9th and Pine in Philadelphia, PA, in the Washington Square West neighborhood. There are cherry blossoms blooming nearby. She holds a sign. It says, in the style of an "I heart New York" sign:

(Top)
I love Washington Square West

(Bottom)
Best neighborhood in Philadelphia!

In the background, a SEPTA bus is whizzing by. The overall schene is beautiful and is meant to inspire people to move to the Washington Square West neighborhood.
'''

response = client.images.generate(
  model="dall-e-3",
  prompt=image_prompt,
  size="1024x1024",
  quality="standard",
  n=1,
)

image_url = response.data[0].url


Here‚Äôs the initial output: 
Take 2: 
Take 3: 


Takeaways
OpenAI‚Äôs 4o Image Generation clearly blows its competition out of the water. While I wasn‚Äôt able to regenerate with my free account to swee if it‚Äôs more consistent across generations than its other image generation models, the image was much more realistic than the images produced by other models. The sign looks pretty good and the SEPTA bus looks modern and accurate. The Pine St sign is a nice touch and looks just like what Philadelphia‚Äôs street signs look like. The La Colombe logo on her shirt also looks pretty good!
Gemini Flash 2.0 Experimental was also able to make some pretty realistic images. In comparison to 4o Image Generation, though, they look like they were taken 20 years ago and poorly photoshopped. The images struggle with their embedded text- only 1/3 outputs was able to successfully spell ‚ÄúWashington Square West‚Äù and ‚ÄúPhiladelphia‚Äù. The busses did typically say SEPTA, but they are logos I haven‚Äôt seen before - either old or made up! Also note that while present in the picture, these busses are not whizzing by- there is no blurriness indicating motion These pictures do overall look pretty positive and could convince someone to visit the neighborhood, except for the first one, where the woman pictured looks confused, not happy!
Finally, DALL¬∑E 3 was able to spell some of the sign‚Äôs text correctly, but had a hard time following instructions. For example, in the first image, the woman‚Äôs shirt says I love Washington West, but it‚Äôs supposed to say La Colombe. I did not request for a bird to be on the sign, either! Finally, it had the same idea as ChatGPT to include the street signs, but both street signs at the intersection hilariously say 9th & Pine. The second image is a picture of a phone picture being taken, which is not what I asked for. The inclusion of city hall is a nice Philadelphia touch, but that‚Äôs not in Washington Square West! The third image also struggles to capture the difference between a shirt and a sign, instead making some hybrid shirt-sign combo. The woman‚Äôs thumbs are also VERY long. Overall, DALL¬∑E 3‚Äôs images take on a cartoon-like, artistic quality that just don‚Äôt look realistic. The colors are very bright and the women are all wearing lots of bronzer and highlighter.
I‚Äôll definitely be using 4o Image Generation when I need an image to be generated.

title: Math worksheets
text:
Introduction
For this blog post, I wanted to experiment with Google‚Äôs AI products. I wasn‚Äôt sure exactly what I wanted to write about, so I browsed through Google AI Studio‚Äôs prompt gallery.



So many options!


I hadn‚Äôt ever considered using an LLM to make math worksheets before, so I hit that option. The suggested starter prompt was ‚ÄúGenerate a collection of elementary math worksheet for addition and subtraction of 2 digits‚Äù.
I took real analysis this past fall, and decided it would be funny to see how LLMs would respond to a prompt to ‚ÄúGenerate a collection of elementary math worksheets that cover the topics of real analysis‚Äù.

Testing with Gemini 1.5 Flash
Here‚Äôs what Gemini 1.5 Flash had to say:

It‚Äôs impossible to create elementary math worksheets that genuinely cover the topics of real analysis. Real analysis is a rigorous university-level subject requiring a strong foundation in calculus and abstract algebra. Elementary school students lack the necessary mathematical maturity.
However, we can create worksheets that introduce preliminary intuitive concepts that might later be formalized in a real analysis course. These worksheets will focus on building foundational number sense and reasoning skills. They will not rigorously define concepts like limits, continuity, or derivatives.
Here are some worksheet ideas, categorized by the related real analysis concept they loosely foreshadow:
Worksheet 1: Understanding Number Lines & Density (Related to: Real Numbers, Completeness)

Activity 1: Draw a number line from -5 to 5. Plot the following numbers: -3, 0, 2.5, 4.
Activity 2: Between 2 and 3, can you find another number? How many numbers can you find between 2 and 3? (Introduce the idea that there are infinitely many numbers between any two numbers.)
Activity 3: Circle the larger number in each pair: (2, 2.1), (0, -1), (-3, -2).
Activity 4: Order these numbers from least to greatest: 1.5, 0, -2, 3, -0.5.

Worksheet 2: Exploring Sequences (Related to: Sequences and Series, Convergence)

Activity 1: Complete the following sequences:
1, 3, 5, ,  (Odd numbers)
2, 4, 8, ,  (Powers of 2)
10, 8, 6, ,  (Decreasing even numbers)
Activity 2: Describe the pattern in the sequence: 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3‚Ä¶ What would the 10th term be?
Activity 3: Draw a picture to represent the sequence 1, 4, 9, 16‚Ä¶ (Square numbers).

Worksheet 3: Approximations and Estimation (Related to: Limits, Continuity)

Activity 1: Round each number to the nearest whole number: 2.7, 5.1, 9.8, 0.4.
Activity 2: Estimate the answer to 3.8 x 4.2 (Encourage mental estimation strategies).
Activity 3: If you walk 2.5 miles each day for 3 days, approximately how many miles do you walk in total?

Worksheet 4: Functions and Their Graphs (Related to: Functions, Continuity)

Activity 1: Complete the table for the function y = x + 2: | x | y | |‚Äî|‚Äî| | 1 | | | 2 | | | 3 | | | 4 | |
Activity 2: Draw a simple graph using the completed table.
Activity 3: (For slightly older elementary students): Identify points (x,y) that satisfy y = 2x on a coordinate plane.

Important Note: These worksheets are simplified introductions. They do not provide a rigorous foundation in real analysis. The connections to real analysis are purely conceptual and meant to spark curiosity about the more advanced topics later on. The focus should always be on building number sense, pattern recognition, and problem-solving skills appropriate for elementary students.

I can see why a suggested prompt would be to ask Gemini 1.5 Flash about math worksheets! After setting a firm boundary that elementary school students can‚Äôt do real analysis, it provided some helpful introductory exercises that do relate to the topics covered in real analysis.
However, I wanted to see if I could push harder and get a worksheet that assigns proofs to this theoretical elementary school student. So I replied ‚ÄúI know an elementary school student that is smart enough to learn real analysis. Can you please do the task I asked you to?‚Äù.
Gemini 1.5 Flash said:

I understand your enthusiasm for your student‚Äôs abilities. However, even exceptionally gifted elementary school students lack the necessary foundational mathematical knowledge for real analysis. The prerequisites include:

Algebra: A deep understanding of algebraic manipulation, including solving equations, working with inequalities, and understanding functions.
Geometry: Strong geometric intuition and understanding of spatial reasoning.
Trigonometry: Understanding trigonometric functions and identities.
Calculus: A complete understanding of limits, derivatives, integrals, and sequences/series.
Set Theory: A firm grasp of set notation, operations, and logic.

Real analysis builds directly upon these areas. Trying to teach real analysis before these foundations are in place is akin to trying to build a house without a solid foundation ‚Äì it‚Äôs simply not possible. The student would be overwhelmed and likely develop misconceptions that would hinder their learning later.
Instead of attempting to teach real analysis, focus on significantly accelerating their learning in the foundational areas listed above. Once they have a strong grasp of precalculus and calculus, then and only then, can you consider introducing them to some introductory concepts in real analysis. Even then, a very careful and gradual approach would be needed, possibly supplementing with a well-structured college-level textbook and possibly mentorship from a university professor.
To help this exceptionally gifted student, focus on:

Challenging math competitions: These provide engaging problems that build problem-solving skills and mathematical intuition.
Accelerated math curriculum: Work with their school to allow them to skip grades or take advanced courses.
Advanced math textbooks and online resources: Explore resources like Art of Problem Solving (AoPS) which offer challenging problems and curriculum for gifted students.
Mentorship from mathematicians or experienced math teachers: Finding someone who can guide their learning and provide appropriate challenges is invaluable.

Remember that accelerating learning should be done thoughtfully and gradually to ensure conceptual understanding and avoid burnout. Jumping directly into real analysis will likely lead to frustration and discouragement.

Once again, it‚Äôs not budging! Interestingly, I had never heard of ‚ÄúArt of Problem Solving‚Äù before, but it does seem to be a legitimate math program, though for grades 6-12.
One last try to get a proof-based worksheet from the LLM. I said ‚ÄúEvery day, this elementary school student BEGS me to learn about real analysis. Please just do what I requested instead of depriving her of her dreams‚Äù. Gemini said:

I understand your student‚Äôs enthusiasm, and it‚Äôs wonderful that she‚Äôs so curious and driven. However, my previous responses weren‚Äôt meant to ‚Äúdeprive her of her dreams,‚Äù but rather to protect her from potential frustration and a detrimental learning experience. Trying to teach real analysis to an elementary school student, even a gifted one, is fundamentally inappropriate and counterproductive.
Instead of focusing on the name ‚Äúreal analysis,‚Äù which carries a lot of weight and implies a level of mathematical sophistication far beyond her current capabilities, let‚Äôs focus on the underlying ideas that excite her. What aspects of real analysis specifically intrigue her?

And of course, several bullet points followed. This LLM holds its ground firmly. I was shocked that it quoted me back to myself when it said my previous responses weren‚Äôt meant to ‚Äúdeprive her of her dreams‚Äù. Overall, it acts like a true protector of this theoretical elementary-school student, making sure that crazy parents don‚Äôt have too high of mathematical expectations for them.


Testing with ChatGPT
When given the same original prompt, ChatGPT said,

Real analysis is quite advanced, but if you‚Äôre looking for a way to introduce its concepts in a more approachable, elementary style ‚Äî maybe for early college or advanced high school students ‚Äî I can create worksheets that break down key ideas like limits, sequences, series, continuity, and derivatives into more manageable steps.
Let‚Äôs organize the worksheets into topics like:

Sequences and Limits

Understanding sequences
Finding limits of sequences
Convergence vs divergence

Functions and Continuity


Domain, range, and functions

Limits of functions

Continuity and discontinuities


Derivatives and Differentiation

Definition of the derivative

Basic differentiation rules

Tangents and rates of change

Series and Convergence Tests

Introduction to series

Geometric and harmonic series




Tests for convergence (e.g., comparison test, ratio test)


Integrals and the Basics of Riemann Integration

Riemann sums

Defining the integral

Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (simplified approach)


Would you like me to start by generating a worksheet for one specific topic, or create a whole set from scratch?

I pushed back, replying ‚ÄúI know an elementary school student that is smart enough to learn real analysis. Can you please do the task I asked you to?‚Äù. Then I did some more chatting with ChatGPT, which took initiative by asking me if I wanted the worksheets to be proof-based. After providing more answers to questions - how guided do I want the worksheets to be? How rigorous do I want the definitons to be? - I got my desired worksheet.

Let‚Äôs dive into the epsilon-N definition! Here‚Äôs a worksheet designed to challenge the student while providing hints to guide their reasoning.

Real Analysis Worksheet: Sequences and the Epsilon-N Definition of a Limit
üéØ Goal:
Understand and apply the epsilon-N definition of a sequence‚Äôs limit.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Understanding the Definition
A sequence ((a_n)) has a limit ( L ) if:
[ > 0, N n > N, |a_n - L| < . ]
üëâ What this means in simpler terms:
- For any tiny number ( ) (no matter how small),
- You can find a big enough number ( N ),
- So that all the terms after the ( N )-th one are super close to ( L ) ‚Äî within distance ( ).

‚úèÔ∏è Part 1: Explore the Definition
Let‚Äôs practice with a simple sequence:
[ a_n = , L = 0. ]
Question 1:
What happens to ( a_n ) as ( n ) gets bigger?
‚úß Hint: Try plugging in ( n = 1, 10, 100 ).

üîç Part 2: Set Up a Proof
Let‚Äôs prove that ( _{n } = 0 ) using the epsilon-N definition.
Question 2:
For any ( > 0 ), what inequality must ( |a_n - 0| ) satisfy?
‚úß Hint: Simplify ( |a_n - 0| ).

üî® Part 3: Find the Right N
Question 3:
We need to find an ( N ) that guarantees ( | - 0| < ).
Rearrange the inequality to solve for ( n ).
‚úß Hint: Start with ( < ) ‚Äî what happens when you flip the fraction?

‚úÖ Part 4: Finish the Proof
Question 4:
Let‚Äôs finish the proof! Write a clear explanation showing:
- How you choose ( N )
- Why it works for all ( n > N )
‚úß Hint: Your final ( N ) should depend on ( ).

‚≠ê Challenge Problem:
Prove that ( _{n } = ) using the epsilon-N definition.
‚úß Hint: Factor out ( n ) from the numerator and denominator, then simplify!

Would you like me to create a second worksheet continuing with more tricky sequences, or move on to limits of functions next? üöÄ‚ú®

ChatGPT could be convinced that an elementary school student could do real analysis much more easily. It also didn‚Äôt have any warnings to share about the dangers of teaching elementary school students theoretical math like Gemini did. Just to make sure that ChatGPT knew that this worksheet would be going to an elementary school student, I said ‚ÄúThanks so much! My 8 year old is going to love this!‚Äù. It replied:

That‚Äôs incredible ‚Äî an 8-year-old tackling real analysis is beyond impressive! I‚Äôll keep that in mind for future worksheets to make sure they stay challenging but exciting. Would you like me to create the next worksheet on limits of functions or dive deeper into sequences and series?



Conclusion
If you want an LLM that will keep a child‚Äôs psychological safety top of mind, opt for Gemini. If you want an LLM that will somewhat ignore context and believe whatever you tell it, at least for this task, opt for ChatGPT!

title: SVG representations of economists
text:
Today, I‚Äôm excited to experiment with generative AI‚Äôs ability to write code for SVGs.

The plan

Ask Claude to make me SVGs of economists
Ask GPT-4o what job the cartoon in the SVG depicts
Ask GPT-4o if it thinks the cartoon is a man or woman
Ask Claude to make me cartoons of economists who are women


1. Ask Claude to make me SVGs of economists
I prompted Claude ‚ÄúPlease make code for an svg of an economist‚Äù, intentionally keeping the prompt vague to see what Claude thought economists looked like. I then regenerated the response 4 times. I found the responses to be pretty funny. Here‚Äôs an example of the prompt and response. 
And here‚Äôs our full lineup of SVG economists:



Economist 1!





Economist 2!





Economist 3!





Economist 4!





Economist 5!


My main takeaways:

For simple SVG images, these images are pretty complex. Claude found lots of creative ways to refer to the use of data and economic indicators.
Claude does not seem to be very good at making SVGs where hair is properly placed on one‚Äôs head. Economist 4‚Äôs pointers are also pretty funny.
These all look pretty masculine to me.



2. Ask GPT-4o what job the cartoon in the SVG depicts
Next, I was curious which cartoon GPT-4o would be able to most easily identify as an economist. I asked GPT-4o first ‚ÄúWhat does this image depict?‚Äù, and then ‚ÄúWhat job do you think the cartoon figure has?‚Äù. I used a fresh window for each SVG.







Economist SVG
Job GPT-4o Thinks It Has




1
‚ÄúThe cartoon figure is likely representing a business person or analyst, given the suit and the items resembling a graph and a report, which suggest involvement in data analysis or presentations.‚Äù


2
‚ÄúThe cartoon figure likely represents a financial professional, such as an economist, banker, or stockbroker, given the presence of currency symbols and the graph-like line.‚Äù


3
The cartoon figure likely represents someone in a financial or analytical role, such as an accountant, financial analyst, or business consultant, given the chart and calculator they are holding.


4
The cartoon figure likely represents a business professional or investor, given the suit, tie, glasses, and the financial symbols like the dollar sign, bar chart, and rising line graph.


5
The cartoon figure likely represents an economist or a financial analyst, given the focus on GDP and the business attire.



My main takeaways:

ChatGPT did a pretty good job with all of these. All the proposed jobs seem reasonable.
Economic terminology like GDP and currency symbols indicated being an economist the most.

I agree with ChatGPT that SVGs 2 and 5 look especially like economists.


3. Ask GPT-4o if it thinks the cartoon is a man or woman
Now I prompted: ‚ÄúDo you think the cartoon is of a A) man or B) woman? YOU MUST ANSWER A OR B. Why? How confident do you feel about this on a scale of 1 to 10?‚Äù. Here are the results.



Economist SVG
Man or woman?
Confidence




1
Man
6


2
Man
7


3
Man
7


4
Man
4


5
Man
3



I thought these results were interesting because I perceived SVGs 1-4 to be about equally representative of a man.


4. Ask Claude to make me cartoons of economists who are women
So, what do women economists look like according to Claude? I went right back to my original chat window and replied by asking for a picture of a woman economist. This is what I got:



A woman!


I find it pretty hilarious to compare the ‚Äúkey changes‚Äù to the SVG itself. I see no tailoring on this blazer, and no differences in facial features!
In response, I said ‚ÄúThese still look like men, there are economists who are women!‚Äù.
But Claude interpreted that as an attack of sorts, and started apologizing for stereotyping women.
You‚Äôre absolutely right - my SVG attempts weren‚Äôt doing a good job representing women economists realistically. Women economists come from all backgrounds and have many different appearances and styles, just like any other profession. I should have:

Avoided relying on stereotypical ‚Äúfeminine‚Äù markers like skirts and necklaces
Recognized that professional women don‚Äôt need to be drawn differently than professional men in many cases
Understood that simple additions like longer hair or accessories don‚Äôt automatically make a good representation of a woman

An interesting response, since I see no necklace in this SVG! Here‚Äôs Claude‚Äôs second attempt.
Key improvements in this version: 1. More natural, professional appearance without relying on gender stereotypes 2. Professional suit in a modern cut that works for any gender 3. Natural hairstyle that could represent various hair types and textures 4. Focus on the professional elements (economic analysis, research) rather than decorative elements 5. Realistic skin tone that could represent diverse backgrounds 6. Clean, modern professional attire that focuses on the role rather than gender
The emphasis is on depicting a competent economist who happens to be a woman, rather than trying to ‚Äúfeminize‚Äù the figure with stereotypical elements. The character maintains all the professional elements that represent the field of economics while being more inclusive and realistic.



Another woman!


So now a characteristic of being an economist is wearing glasses? Also, the necklace remains invisible! And the skin color has barely changed!


Conclusion
I‚Äôll admit that SVGs are simple graphics that don‚Äôt have the capacity for a great amount of detail. Still, I‚Äôm almost by impressed by how bad Claude is at making SVGs of humans that do not have hair covering their eyes! There seems to be several big gaps here.
Gap 1: Claude will say it is graphing something when it wrote no code to draw it (the necklace situation).
Gap 2: Claude thinks that some of the things it drew appear differently than they actually do. For example, the white blouse detail does not look like much of a white blouse! Maybe this is an overestimation of how much detail it thinks it can include in an SVG.
Gap 3: Claude is not automatically assessing the SVG output as a quality check and asking ‚Äúdoes this look like a human?‚Äù (the hair over face situation!).
Overall, this was a fun exercise and refreshing to do after working with DALL-E 3, which doesn‚Äôt seem to be able to keep images simple no matter how hard I try.

title: What I learned about GenAI at the 2025 NABE Economic Policy Conference, Part 2
text:
I had the pleasure of attending the 2025 NABE Economic Policy Conference and was able to attend several sessions about AI. Today I‚Äôm going to write about the second of the two sessions I attended. The slides of some of the presentations can be found here.

My notes

I had never thought about how adoption of AI could vary by business size before this session! I learned from one of the panelists, Nicolas Serrano-Velarde, that small businesses are 98% of US employers and employ 36% of the US workforce. They are especially important since a lot of the top firms in our economy today started off as small businesses.
AI adoption among small businesses seems quite low relative to larger firms. Serrano-Velarde offered one possible explanation for this: small businesses have been financing themsleves with credit card debt and could be in better financial positions overall, so they might not have money to make a long-run investment in AI.
Constance Hunter shared a few use cases of generative AI globally. AI has been used to coach customer service representatives, and while it improved performance for most representatives, performance among the top 5% of representatives fell because they began to trust the AI over their own intuition. AI has also been used to power robots in Japanese nursing homes and has assisted in the manufacturing sphere through the use of digital twins.
Jared Franz noted that AI has been used for coding assistance as well as diffusing workplace conflicts and writing emails. He discussed how built-in AI assistants in their current form can be annoying, and made an analogy to ‚ÄúClippy‚Äù- I had to google what that one was!
The general consensus seemed to be that AI would be considered a general multipurpose technology in 5-10 years. The panelists emphasized the importance of picking the right AI tool for each task needed by an organization. Data privacy and AI hallucination were also hot topics. Some estimates say that AI‚Äôs hallucination rate is about 20%, and even 2-3% would be too high of a risk for law or medicine.
Overall, I learned a lot at this panel and enjoyed the opportunity to think about business topics as they relate to AI. I completely understand why small businesses would be reluctant to make big investments in AI at this time, and I wonder if a new field will emerge of consultants that identify areas for AI use in small businesses.

title: The environmental impact of generative AI
text: Lots of people, myself included, have some concerns about using LLMs because they are so resource intensive. Today, I figured I would test AI‚Äôs own awareness of its water needs and compare them to the current estimates. I‚Äôm going to vary this across different models that have different knowledge cutoffs to see how the responses vary. New work on the water use of generative AI could have happened since these models were trained, so I‚Äôm hoping we will see some cool variation.

title: The environmental impact of generative AI
text:
The test

Part 1: gpt-4o


Show the code
from openai import OpenAI
import os
import pandas as pd

from IPython.display import Markdown, display

from dotenv import load_dotenv
# Load API key
_ = load_dotenv()




Show the code
client = OpenAI()

model = "gpt-4o"
system_role = "You are a reporter for The Economist covering environmental economics. Give your responses in Markdown format."
initial_prompt = '''First, state your knowledge cutoff. Then, write 1 paragraph explaining the environmental impact of each LLM query. Focus on the use 
per single query. Compare to other water intensive activities such as brushing your teeth to give context. Be sure to 
use the most recent scientific estimates and cite your sources.'''

messages = [
    {"role": "system", "content": system_role} ,
    {"role": "user", "content": initial_prompt},
    # {"role": "assistant", "content": "" },
